awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Developing Youth Data Literacies through a Visual Programming Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
This research investigates blocks-based programming with everyday information as a vehicle for teaching secondary school youth data science skills. Professional opportunities in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) and beyond increasingly require abilities for making sense of data. These skills require literacies involving data collection, processing, visualization, and analysis. This project investigates new ways to foster these data literacies in middle and high-school-aged students. New software and educational material will be publicly available for learners and educators to use. Workshops for youth will involve the Teen Science Café, run by the Morehead Planetarium and Science Center. Through this investigation, the project is expected to advance knowledge of how to support youth in developing data-centric problem-solving skills, while enabling them to program with everyday information.

A data-focused, visual block-based programming environment will be created. The environment will enable students to manipulate and experience everyday data sources with filtering and information visualization. This programming environment will be developed iteratively through formative research studies involving young people. Qualitative and quantitative results from these studies will be used to both improve the design of the system, as well as to create new knowledge addressing misconceptions and difficulties that kids experience as they engage with data concepts and practices. The goal of this project is to have young people invent and develop their own data tools, rather than only use them. It is expected to advance scientific understanding of (1) design principles and best practices for creating visual, block-based data programming toolkits that can engage youth with diverse interests in programming with data; and (2) misconceptions and difficulties faced by youth while learning to program with data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed and evaluated new ways to support children in learning how to analyze and visualize data - an increasingly important skill in today's data-driven society. As a part of this project, the project developed a new visual block-based programming language for doing data analysis, conducted seven research workshops with a total of 27 children to understand how they used this new programming language to do data analysis, as well as common misconceptions and difficulties that they encountered in the process. The data analysis tasks that the children participating in the research carried out were framed in terms of data stories developed by the project - for example, for one of the data stories, children had to imagine themselves as helping a penguin find their lost cousin through solving a series of data analysis tasks.

Research findings from this project include the following:

  • Certain features of block-based languages made it easier to get started with data analysis through programming. For example, rather than type the name of a column in tabular data, in a block-based language, one can select from a drop-down menu that already contains the names of the columns.

  • While doing data analysis, children not only developed understanding concepts that are key for data literacy (e.g., knowing what filtering a dataset means), but also started to develop data literacy practices (e.g., cross checking tabular and visual representation of data to ensure correctness), as well as data literacy perspectives (e.g., acknowledging that data can be incomplete and messy). This suggests that data literacy can be seen as having multiple dimensions, and children develop skills in each of these dimensions as they engage in data analysis projects.

  • In some cases, existing knowledge of programming had to be accounted for to support children in doing data analysis effectively. For example, to filter a dataset, one strategy that was observed to be initially considered was the use of loops, which is commonly taught in any introductory programming lesson, instead of the new "filter" block that the project's programming language introduced. While a loop could have worked in theory, a better alternative to filter data was to use the "filter" block directly. This suggests that educators teaching data literacy need to be aware of such conceptual adjustments and guide students as needed.

  • The project introduced data stories to add context and meaning to the data analysis activities. However, data stories seemed to have some drawbacks as well. For example, when asked about what else data analysis could be used for beyond the research workshop activities, at least one research participant gave an answer that was very similar to the task that they had just carried out (finding a lost animal). This suggests that contextualizing data analysis activities through a background story can potentially limit a learner's imagination in terms of the possibilities offered by data analysis.

Intellectual merit: This project contributed to an understanding of (1) how to design visual block-based programming languages for data analysis, and (2) how children develop competencies in data analysis and visualization through programming, including insights into common difficulties that they face in the process.

Broader impacts: Being able to analyze and visualize data is an important ability not only for aspiring STEM workers, but also for anyone living in today's data-driven and data-mediated society. The project engaged 27 children in a series of seven research workshops where they learned to write code to do data analysis and visualization. The project also supported one faculty member, three graduate students, and four undergraduate students in developing their research careers and skills. The software and accompanying educational material from the project has been made available to the public through the project website.
